utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Katie Pavlich, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” America, are you ready for this?

utterances.speaker: SEN. CORY BOOKER, D-N.J.
utterances.utterance: This is about the closest I'll probably ever have in my life to an I am Spartacus moment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Senator Cory Booker joining the already crowded 2020 Democratic presidential field. Booker on The View today explaining why he's running and also defending his Spartacus moment.

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.utterance: I'm running to restore our sense of common purpose, to focus on the common pain that we have all over this country. We can do better. That was one of my prouder moments sticking up for people. And when I was threatened to be thrown out of the Senate, I told the senator to bring it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And 2020 hopeful, Elizabeth Warren, now apologizing to the Cherokee nation for taking a DNA test to prove she has Native American ancestry. Warren also continuing to go after billionaires.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.utterance: I want these billionaires to stop being free loaders. I want them to pick up their fair share. That's how we make a system that works not just for the rich and for the powerful but works for all of us. All I'm asking for is a little slice from the tippy-tippy top.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez causing controversy for calling for a 70 percent tax on the wealthiest Americans. But another freshman representative saying it needs to be even higher than that.

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN OMAR, D-MINN.
utterances.utterance: You could increase the taxes that people are paying who are the extremely wealthy in our community, so 70 percent, 80 percent. We've had it as high as 90 percent. I'm also one that really looks at the defense budget that we have. That has increased nearly 50 percent since 9/11.

utterances.utterance: I don't think that too hard because that would be a uniter not a divider, right? Which is the Obama message, right? Hope not fear. And then you go back to actually George W. Bush, compassion. You can back to Bill Clinton, you know, the kid from hope. So I think it's possible to be a uniter and say I'm not fracturing the country like the incumbent. But I just wanted to say to Jesse, I think I've known Cory Booker a little longer than you have. And I remember when he had to run against an incumbent black mayor in Newark, they've made a film about this, Sharpe James. And he was a guy who took him on and lost, got beaten before he became mayor. Secondly, he cut the size of the government workforce in Newark. He drove down crime. I think this was before the state budget cuts required some police --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, crime went up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, crime went down but then it went back up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, over all it went up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. But I'm just saying he came in and took steps that decreased the crime rate in a crime ridden city which is Newark, New Jersey.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. By the time he left, Newark was the third highest murder per-capita behind Detroit and New Orleans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because of larger -- that's like saying -- no, that's like saying when Obama came in the economy collapsed. That's not necessarily --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm talking about the end of the term.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying. All right. And the other thing I want to say is on an issue that's very important to me, school choice, school vouchers, guess what? Cory Booker is terrific. And I think conservatives need to be aware of this that he's the one who was willing to say we've got to do better by kids giving them more choice. Giving parents the power --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But you're making -- you're helping to make Greg's point --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. You just made my point. That's OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- which is that Cory Booker is bucking the party on a lot of things. Let me ask you though, his first endorsement came in today, Senator Bob Menendez, has a little ethical problem, he just got reelected very handedly .

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did he endorse him with his shirt off?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think so. It's a little cold outside. They're not in Puerto Rico.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, look, Bob Menendez is a powerful voice in the Senate. He's someone who's been there for a long time. Cory Booker needs endorsement in the Democratic Party. He's going to have a tough time getting ahead of the field. All of his work in the Senate has really been about, you know, asking tough questions or falsely accusing Brett Kavanaugh, not giving him any due process. It hasn't been about results legislation. But what there is a record of that doesn't exist in Washington for Cory Booker is his record as mayor. When he left, violent crime in Newark -- violent crime meaning murder, assault, sexual assault -- went up by 33 percent. That's a pretty significant margin especially if you're trying to run against President Donald Trump who's been all about trying to reduce violent crime. The other thing too is, yes, he has been for education. He is definitely for choosing schools, absolutely good. But there are a lot of questions about corruption during his time in Newark about giving out contracts to his politically affiliated buddies. There's a lot of money that was given by Facebook that kind of disappeared and didn't go to education as was promised. And so -- and also, I think his comments on race. He has to be very careful about using race as a way to campaign while also not accusing the entire country and people he needs to vote for him in the middle of the country of being racist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Before we go --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I set a little standard here and just tell you the first mayor in 45 years in Newark not to leave under indictment. I mean, that's --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a low bar.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's a low bar. But I just wanted to point out -- you know, if you talk about corruption in Newark, this ain't Cory Booker.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No. He has done -- there was one other development today -- we've talk about Elizabeth Warren and her candidacy a lot. She did make a call today to the Cherokee nation, Jesse, to apologize about the DNA test to prove she had Native American ancestry. And the Cherokee nation accepted the apology and hoped that this would put an end to this. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you remember that book Choose Your Own Adventure --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- as a child? Do you know how if you made the wrong decision over and over and over again you would just lose? This is what she's done. She should've never had claimed she was a Native American.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not about the DNA test.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She should've never had taken the DNA test, and then -- she should have never apologized.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: She should have never said she was a minority. She should have never listed herself as a minority to get ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This bunch, they truly are a sorry bunch, so many apologies in the last month already. I think you have to apologize in order to become a candidate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think there -- this is being misframed because I think what she apologized was -- the apology was about the Native Americans saying we'll determine who's a member of our tribe. It's not up to blood tests --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's what I've just said about the DNA test.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, so it's not -- she didn't apologize for taking the DNA test.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, we don't actually know what she apologized for. You can see he letter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She apologized for anyone who said that would be the basis of her inclusion as a member of that tribe.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We have seen the letters. We know exactly what it was.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That is splitting a pretty fine hair.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Next, a California chef facing backlash after saying he would refuse service to people wearing MAGA hats, believe it or not. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: A California chef is now apologizing after getting burned for saying he would refuse service to customers who come in wearing a MAGA hat. The chef since deleting the tweet after making the threat where he also compared the hat to a swastika and a white hood. CNN hosts talking about this issue last night after claiming they don't support these types of bans, they then said this.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CUOMO, CNN HOST
utterances.utterance: You can refuse service. You know, no shirt, no shoes, no service. How is this any different than the baker with the cake? Well, that was about refusing service to a group of people that should be a protected class.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN HOST
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CUOMO
utterances.utterance: And unless you could argue that Trump supporters should be a protected class, I don't think you have much of an argument on that. I don't want to fall into the trap of under selling the significance of the trigger of the expression to people.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.utterance: Your clothing tells a story about who you are, what you think about, and what you represent. That hat means everything from -- I would say the beginning of the campaign, maybe before, maybe that hat means the central part five (ph) to people, maybe it means birtherism to people, Maybe it means, you know, Mexicans are rapist to people.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Or maybe it just means make America great again, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like they share one brain. It really is sweet. Look, we've talked about this before. It's not really about a hat. It's about the expansion of a target by the media. And it is the media's responsibility. It's not -- it's not -- it's no longer about Trump and it's no longer about voting for Trump because if you're not part of the resistance that's enabling. You're just like a storm trooper, right? Remember, you're just like a Nazi if you're not part -- you know, the thing is -- it's not about Trump. It's not about a hat. It's not about voting anymore. It's about just -- any kind of extension to Trump. So they have widened -- they widened the target now so that it's a cultural witch-hunt. You keep shaking your head, Juan, but we have so many examples of this. It's a cultural witch-hunt for anybody, and it's sanctioned by people like Lemon who say, OK, if you're not part of our group you're evil. This is really bad because we're demonizing half the country.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So let me respond, say, the MAGA hats for a lot of people says, if you're not part of our group you're evil.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Make America Great.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And I think it is a provocative statement. Now, you know, on the face of it I say it's a piece of clothing. That's my -- the fact that I view it as a provocative piece of clothing --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But why do you do that? Why do you that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think Don Lemon and I think Cuomo were on target.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where did you get the idea?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, where is the idea?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. I want to know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you, how about David Duke wearing it? How about Caesar say, I think, shooting people when they're riding on the Trump truck holding a MAGA hat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So when a racist drinks orange juice, do you then say no more orange juice to me?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. But I'm saying --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't drink orange juice because racist drink orange juice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. But I'm saying, I thought they made a very good point, Greg, when they said it's a protected class matter of discrimination. Protected class is by gender, by sex, my disability. It's not my political belief.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm OK with them saying -- you know the chef, he's paying his price. That's the way the market should work. If you make a decision, then you pay the price.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So it's a free market decision. It's like Nike saying we're backing Colin Kaepernick right now. They've made a decision. This guy apologized. By the way, you know what he apologized to? He apologized to the people who work at the restaurant and his co-investors because it might cause someone not to come to the restaurant. He didn't apologize for saying MAGA hats are provocative.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he didn't -- he claims that he's apologizing. He has a right not to serve people he doesn't want to serve in his restaurants. It's a private business. He can do what he wants. But, Jesse, he didn't really apologize because he then went on to say in his apology that the hat symbolizes anger, hate, and violence. So, you know, it's like own it or not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, if Kanye came in rocking the hat, I wonder if he'd serve Kanye West. I think he would. And the difference between the baker deal, I mean, the baker who is a Christian, when you're asked to bake a gay wedding cake and you're asked to say, you know -- you know, God bless, you know, Dick and John, and there's two guys in the middle, that he was arguing that you then complicit in making a cake that, you know, doesn't represent your Christian values. If you're just serving burgers and fries, you're not participating --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Not forcing the chef to wear a MAGA hat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly. It's a totally different analogy. And then, you know, as someone with the authority on sweeping generalizations.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think that what CNN is doing is to say that this hat represents this to so many people -- permission to make an analogy?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would love to see it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If you have a New England Patriots hat --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's going to make --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- to some people that might represent cheating, and Spygate, and double homicide, Hernandez, steroids --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: By some people, Jesse means him. Some people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: To other people that could just mean the Patriots and winning. So I think when this country tells you don't wear this clothing, drive this car, stop saying Merry Christmas, baby it's cold outside is about rape. This is the reason Donald Trump became elected because we're so sick of people telling them what to do, how to think, and what to say.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But, Dana, the media continues to allow these comparisons to fly without any context. So they continue to say that it represents a KKK hood without any context about what the KKK actually did, and saying that a MAGA hat is equal to that. I feel like that down plays the severity of what the KKK was and something that we have eradicated from most part in this country and not something that we actually condone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: For yearbooks.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Except for a yearbook for Democrats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The sweeping generalizations aren't necessarily just only Jesse's specialty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Whataboutism.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We have that too. It's also another example of why grown people should get off Twitter. And if you think that this is -- he's going to have to apologize to your partners and your -- it's like Twitter is diminishing people's lives.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And we have to all --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Get off.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- commit and get off it then.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, look, I don't --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- every week.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's a good idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We should kill this business. For -- we should -- I don't know - - they're using us. We're not getting paid to tweet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How am I going to promote my show?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Nobody on Twitter --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nobody on Twitter listens to any promos. In fact, they hate the promotions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That tweet about that last week was very funny.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. It's like nobody likes to be told --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I saw it on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right. This is actually social media is what we're talking about next. So, up next, could you give up social media for a month? Greg is going to mandate it. What happens when you do?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hello. If you're addicted to social media, listen up. A new study shows that staying off of Facebook for one month can improve your overall well-being. If you can do it, researchers say expect more in person time with your family and friends, an extra hour of down time for yourself, and a small bump, this is really important, in your daily mood and satisfaction with life. Now, in the break, we were having a discussion at the table because we have a bunch of people who are addicted to social media. And I asked you, has it -- is it better to be on it or off it, what do you say?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think it's a good -- it's like everything else in moderation. But I have to say this study paid people to be off of it for a month. So if I was getting paid to be off of it, I would -- it would improve my mood to do that, I think.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's a hundred bucks.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think it depends on how --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I will take a hundred bucks.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly. I think it depends on how you use Facebook or social media. If you're using it to catch up with friends you don't get to see a lot or you're using it for your own personal reasons then it's good. If you're using it to have political fights with your cousins or your uncles on Facebook when you should actually be sitting down and having dinner with them instead, that probably puts your mood into a damper.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, Katie makes an important point, Jesse. It said that, in fact, polarization, political polarization among the group that abstained went way down, 10 percent down in that period.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Limbaugh always says if you want to, you know, take a weekend off or a week off and just don't watch television, don't go on social media, you realize, you know, sky is not falling, the world is not ending. And generally, people around you, your neighbors, the people at the store are nice people. They're not trying to cut your throat out and scream about, you know, guns, abortion, and --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Your MAGA hat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And your MAGA hat, exactly. And what has it taught anybody anything, Juan, is that ignorance is bliss. I used to interview people on the street and ask them all types of questions about current events and they had no idea, but they were very happy people.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They were.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's fine.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's because they were drunk half the time on a beach. That's why they're happy people. They're in the sun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Was that an endorsement that most of these people are ignorant?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can take it that way, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought -- what is your response?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not ignorant, just uninformed.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Uninformed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Uninformed. Dana, what do you make of this? Could you do it, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, especially if I got a hundred bucks. I could do it. But, OK, this is like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You could buy a Facebook ad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Of all the things that I think are the biggest threat to Facebook as a company is I don't think it's fake news, I don't think it's foreign influence. I think it is these studies that show people -- this is a product that can make you sick. It can make you unhappy. It can make you depressed. And if you have more of this, I think that is actually -- it's not what Mark Zuckerberg imagined. This was going to bring everyone together and there's going to be utopia. I feel like of all the studies and all the things that they've had to deal with at Facebook, this would be the one to me that is the most troubling.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can I just say one more thing just to not -- I don't mean to cut you off. I heard from a source that a lot of these executives at the social media companies don't allow their own children to have all the face time with the social media.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I donŸ_Tt know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And this is the other thing I'm going to suggest. This was a study -- get off for a month. If you try this even if you don't get a hundred bucks, imagine how cool it would be if on a Saturday morning, once a month, you're like I'm going to check in and see what my friends from college are doing. I want to see the kid's picture, the baby and the dog pictures and which is like once a month, it would be something you really looked forward to and that you weren't wasting all your time with. And there is a startup opportunity out there. If you could figure out the way for us to be able to get news like we want it without the rest of the stuff, that business could really do well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, guess what Greg. So, you know on our network at 8 PM Tucker Carlson.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Tucker Carlson says that too much use of smartphones and social media leads to higher suicide rates, more loneliness and he says, why don't we have a law.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There are no laws.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No laws.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hate laws, hate laws. I want a law against laws. We're blaming social media for something that is actually the fault of the media. See, if you get off Twitter, you're not the problem, right. You're not the one that is pushing narratives that make people angry. OK, So, the business model and I've said it before is the prison of two ideas. For the media to make its money, we have to be at each other's throats. That's the bottom-line. So, when you go on Twitter, you're not just seeing people who are getting mad at each other for no reason. They're getting mad because they're reading things from wherever and half of it is wrong. I would say, it's inflammatory. I would say, most of it is wrong. That's why I said like where are you getting your ideas about the mega hat. It's because I'm going like why are people - why is that chef so angry. Well, he read something that made him mad and it's a narrative. So, it's not social media's fault that there is online rage. It's the media that is pushing our buttons and we have to learn never to trust anything on social media, anything even if you see - I've learned this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree with you, 100 percent. But I must say, I don't see why you're making the connection to media, because I think a lot of it is us. It's you know we have met the enemy, it's as we put out provocative statements thinking well, I'm going to become a star because everyone's reacting to me on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, that's true. We all love attention, but we've made this point that by human beings away from this thing actually are OK. Right. We get along. We don't really care who you voted for. We could like for example if you go - if you're fans of the Patriots, one fan could have voted for Obama. The other one could have been for McCain. That doesn't enter the picture when you're rooting for the Patriots. It's when you get on to social media, that's the pollutant, but the pollutant is driven by the media. The media makes everything bad. I wish we didn't have it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, the counterpoint I saw this week was that where local newspapers go away, political polarization increases because people get their news from social media or National ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Narratives.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Can I get one chip real quickly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I have a friend who doesn't want to be on social media during the day, so he locks his phone in one of those lockable food boxes from people who are dieting. And he puts it in the closet. So, he need help getting rid of your phone, that will help you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The problem is the cloud is still outside while your phone is locked. The cloud is still there, and you could come back and find out you're the one being attacked.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but at least you're not the one who's provoking you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A man gets busted for faking this slip and fall Oh! My gosh. That more. Coming up on THE FIVE and Jesse Watters exclusive Fast Seven next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for the Fast Seven. First up, is it me or does Jennifer Lawrence look a little different.

utterances.speaker: JENNIFER LAWRENCE, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: My favorite is probably Lisa Vanderpump. My least favorite, I don't want to have to say, I mean I don't want to have to say because who knows where you're going to run into these people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, this creepy face swap of Jennifer Lawrence and actor Steve Buscemi. It's called deep fake and it's a video where a person's face and their voice are digitally manipulated. And this is a big threat they're saying, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well I looked at the media like when they discover new words. They're calling this deep fake. It's actually - this has been around for years. OK. Do you remember Jack Olo (ph) postcards. The postcard of a giant, the giant jack rabbit.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Grandfather's motel.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And also, I mean it's like - it's just photoshop, but it's really, really good photoshop. And we should be worried because what if a nefarious agent decides to place you in a sick illegal film, right and decides to ruin your life unless you pay him off. That's an industry waiting to happen, and I said this in the previous block, you cannot trust your eyes again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, like if something we see happens like a Covington esque story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the Russians create some sort of really, really provocative incident and makes the whole country go crazy.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I live with some fear that the Daily Briefing will be the first show that has a deep fake video that we take seriously and then view all these apologies. I think about this stuff a lot. What's interesting about the fakes and Photoshop, in 1995, I was in grad school and my thesis was about the doctrine of photographs and journalism. Remember that OJ Simpson. cover shot for Time magazine and it made him look nicer and then ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That was quaint by comparison.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: This is really dangerous and it's already happening especially with revenge ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Trump's pictures.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Especially it's for women and then revenge porn, things like that this is happening.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And domestically it's happening on stuff like that, but the national security community is very concerned about this, because they're worried about events like, events like terrorist attacks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're not worried about Steve Buscemi?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
